name: cable yarder with sled winch production | cable yarder with sled winch | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10859/documentation



The activity starts with the semi-finished products and raw materials at the factory gate.

The inventory accounts for the input and disposal of all materials, their (pre-) processing and the energy required for the production and maintenance of the forest machinery represented by this dataset. In addition, material for and emissions from disassembly are included.
Infrastructure for the production and maintenance of the machinery is inventoried as a rough guess from lorry production.
The dataset does not contain fuel consumption or related emissions. These issues are inventoried in the respective dataset on the operation of the machinery.
category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./282:Manufacture of special-purpose machinery/2821:Manufacture of agricultural and forestry machinery

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventories apply to the production in Northern/Central Europe
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
The material composition of the sled based winch yarder incl. carriage is derived from the LCI data for a  truck (according to Spielmann et al. 2007) per relative machine weights, excluding flat glass, and rubber tyres, adjusting the amount of paint and PP based on best guesses. The resulting material difference is complemented with steel  unalloyed up to the total weight of the machinery (excl. cables). Electricity and heat consuption as well as the consumption of tap water and the generation of lorry production effluent and sewage are extrapolated from the dataset on truck production by machine weight. Data for the battery and for infrastructure are assumed to be 10% used for the truck production. The value for aluminium cast has been communicated by a producer; for other materials, no detailed information was available. 

The materialisation and production of the cable are estimated based on the assumptions listed in the comments fields of the dataset.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data modified from Spielmann, M,, L. Barreto, V. Erni, F. Frutig and O.Thees (2007): Life cycle assessment of energy wood supply of forest wood chips in Switzerland, Paul Scherrer Institute and Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research (WSL), unpublished.

exchanges.description: cables: skyline: 1 piece, lenght: 1000 m, thickness: 22 mm, weight: 2.02 kg/m; mainline: 1 pieces, lenght: 1000  m, thickness: 11 mm, weight: 0.502 kg/m; anchoring of end pole and supportive constructions: 6 cables a 80 m, thickness 10 mm; weight 0.45 kg/m and 2 cable a 40 m, thickness 10 mm and a weight of 0.45 kg. The replacement of the cables is considered via a separate maintenance factor. It is not considered that often, cables from cable cars or ski lifts are used that are worn and no longer permitted in such installations for human transport.

exchanges.description: total material input for production and maintenance (estimated via default factor); the amount of material used in production is taken from the reference (value for truck) and complemented up to the total weight of the sled + winch; to this amount, the weight of the carriage and the ancillary material are added.In addtion, the steel used for the cables is added (for respective assumptions, see comment on wire drawing, steel)
